yuku:
In your script, the `args` is already an Array object not `arguments`, so I ran new script as follows: ``` js console.time('for'); (function () { return toArrayUsingFor(arguments); })(args); console.timeEnd('for'); // for: 0.279ms console.time('slice'); (function () { return toArrayUsingSlice(arguments); })(args); console.timeEnd('slice'); // slice: 0.136ms ``` 200% faster!! Thank you for your PR :+1: . Hi! I find that `lock3` described below is much faster than version 1 and 2 :) ``` js var lock3 = function (func) { var free, locked; free = function () { locked = false; }; return function () { var args; if (locked) return; locked = true; args = toArray(arguments); args.unshift(free); func.apply(this, args); } }; var i; i = 0; console.time('lock1'); while (++i < 10000) { lock1(function (free, query) { free(); })({}); } console.timeEnd('lock1'); // => lock1: 72.363ms i = 0; console.time('lock2'); while (++i < 10000) { lock2(function (free, query) { free(); })({}); } console.timeEnd('lock2'); // => lock2: 51.875ms i = 0; console.time('lock3'); while (++i < 10000) { lock3(function (free, query) { free(); })({}); } console.timeEnd('lock3'); // => lock3: 22.819ms ``` So I want to close the PR. Thanks a lot for your PR! . thx! . thx! . thx . Hi, thanks for opening the pull request. Actually the demo page is using jQuery 1.10 but it does not mean the script requires 1.10. In other words I don't want to ban sites using 1.8 or below. BTW, the patch includes good refactoring. Do you mind if I ask you to update the patch as I'll mention later? to support 1.8 or below? Thanks . Are these codes worth optimizing? It seems too complicated to me. Do you have any idea about the trade off among code size, speed and complexity? If it is hard to explain in English, feel free to use 日本語 :) . I have to decide supported jQuery versions. IMO supporting jQuery (>=1.7.0) makes sense because the Backbone also supports the same versions. Any idea? Thanks. . Summary of the above comment: - When we calculate the multiple CSS properties of an element using `jQuery.fn.css`, the efficiency of the method between ver. < 1.8 and >= 1.8 are quite different. - Both of them invokes the `getComputedStyle` native function to get the final used values of all the CSS properties of an element. - In ver. >= 1.8, the jQuery method can be executed with the array of properties. Then the native function will be invoked once. - In ver. < 1.8, we have to execute the jQuery method many times. It means that the native function will also be invoked same times. - Function invocation is really heavy in JavaScript. - Because `jQuery.fn.on` is being used and it is supported by jQuery >= 1.7, supporting 1.7 or later makes sense. - I have already found that the current code can work with jQuery 1.7.2. --- I got it. I did `git rebase gh-pages`. . `getStyles` function is not use an array into argument of `jQuery.fn.css` when using jQuery 1.8 or below. I will use the following condition. jQuery 1.8 or below: ``` javascript typeof $('
').css(['color']).color !== 'undefined'; // => false ``` jQuery 1.9 or later: ``` javascript typeof $('
').css(['color']).color !== 'undefined'; // => true ``` . 英語で意図を伝えられる説明をできる自信が一切ないのでお言葉に甘えさせていただきまして日本語で失礼いたします。 `jQuery.fn.css` は内部的に `window.getComputedStyle` メソッドが実行ごとに呼び出されるようになっています。`window.getComputedStyle` メソッドは引数に与えられた任意の要素 (`HTMLElement` オブジェクトを継承するインスタンス) がどのようにレンダリングされているかのスタイル情報を一括で取得します。そのため `jQuery.fn.css` が複数回実行された場合にスタイル情報の一括取得が、複数回行われてしまうこととなり大きな速度低下を招きます。 jQuery 1.9 以降では `jQuery.fn.css` の引数に配列を与えた場合には、`window.getComputedStyle` メソッドは一度だけ実行されるので大きな速度向上に寄与します。jQuery 1.8 以前の場合は元のコードと変わりない動きをしている (はず) なので速度低下は関数実行コスト以外にはないはずで、最近の JIT を載せた JavaScript 処理系では無視できる速度差です。 ちなみに IE では `window.getComputedStyle` メソッドは存在しないために使えず、`element.currentStyle` プロパティーが使われます。こちらはスタイル情報が一括で入れられている `Object` となっており生成コストは `window.getComputedStyle` メソッドと比べると問題でるようなものではなく、jQuery 1.9 以降だろうと jQuery 1.8 以前だろうと、どちらも速度的な大きな差は生じません。 イベントハンドラーの登録時に `jQuery.fn.on` を用いているので jQuery 1.7 以降をサポートするような形で問題ないと、わたしも考えます。わたし自信は jQuery 2.0.3、jQuery 1.10.2、jQuery 1.9.1、jQuery 1.8.3 で動作問題ないか確認してから Pull Request の送信を行っていますが、先ほど確認しましたところ jQuery 1.7.2 でも本件パッチが動作することを確認しました。 `jQuery.fn.on` ではなく `jQuery.fn.bind` を使うようにすれば jQuery 1.6 以前にも対応させられるのではないかとも思いますが、そこまで古い jQuery に今対応する必要はないかと思います。 . alan2wong:
Rebased. As a note, in case you were wondering why I used height rather than the number of items as the option, this is so that the list items can be set to any size (rather than requiring a constant height). The scroll code is not dependent on the list items all being the same size.
. Rebased. As a note, in case you were wondering why I used height rather than the number of items as the option, this is so that the list items can be set to any size (rather than requiring a constant height). The scroll code is not dependent on the list items all being the same size.
.

. Hi, @lpsBetty –

Please excuse my slow reply. I am on vacation right now.

The precise code I submitted does not appear to be there any longer. But that doesn’t mean the correct support for editable content is gone. For example, the current code does use the `.isContentEditable` boolean, which was one of the things my PR introduced.

But I am not really a project maintainer and I only contributed this one time. I have not followed the project closely since then so I must defer all detailed Q&A about this subject to others. Perhaps I could lend a hand with a new PR if you create an issue outlining the problems you are having and how to reproduce them.

Best.

Best.

teodossidossev:
In our app we may initialize multiple instances of CKEditor in one page. Textcomplete leaks when a CKE instance is destroyed and after that another one is initialized because of the way textcomplete connects to CKE - with CKEditor.on('instanceready'). Textcomplete  attaches its old dropdown menu together with the newly created one to the new instance. And tries to replace twice. If the CKE is destroyed and another one is initialized, then we have three dropdowns an so on. 
If you connect to CKE with CKEditor.once(...) the old dropdowns will never try to  reconnect again and so is the memory leak partly (the dropdowns are not garbage collected) prevented.. In our app we may initialize multiple instances of CKEditor in one page. Textcomplete leaks when a CKE instance is destroyed and after that another one is initialized because of the way textcomplete connects to CKE - with CKEditor.on('instanceready'). Textcomplete  attaches its old dropdown menu together with the newly created one to the new instance. And tries to replace twice. If the CKE is destroyed and another one is initialized, then we have three dropdowns an so on. 
If you connect to CKE with CKEditor.once(...) the old dropdowns will never try to  reconnect again and so is the memory leak partly (the dropdowns are not garbage collected) prevented..
ThomasVandenbon:
Is there any chance that this pull request might still be merged and made into a new version, even though the project is no longer being maintained?

I've been unable to figure out a workaround for this, since there seems to be no way to remove this specific listener from CKeditor.

Note: since the pull request doesn't affect https://github.com/yuku-t/jquery-textcomplete/blob/master/dist/jquery.textcomplete.js#L163, referencing the pull request through npm can't be used as a work-around.

I'd happily switch to the newer https://github.com/yuku-t/textcomplete but sadly it doesn't have CKeditor support yet (see https://github.com/yuku-t/textcomplete/issues/35).. Thank you so much for your speedy intervention, this works brilliantly!. My colleague @beuseli has implemented a better solution, that works for both situations where only a single CKEditor is visible at a time and for situations where multiple are visible on a single page.

See #309 
It would be great if you could merge this pull request and release a new version.
While this pull request (#294) fixed some issues, it also introduced a few new ones. Which is why we decided to make a pull request with a fiddle demonstrating the problems.. Is there any chance that this pull request might still be merged and made into a new version, even though the project is no longer being maintained?
